Sadly we can't do this in the DI, because the config isn't available at bootstrap time. So I'm always injecting dead code unless there's a runtime change to it.
Though perhaps I could manual-wire it instead of using ctor injection. Not really worth that though.
I had it set up where the second function was a function of the first one, but there's an inconsistency (or two) in how timestamps are expected to be formatted, so I had to separate them.

Yeah, I had a use for it but now I can't find it.

nodes.bodyText: Please add a comment about what this means
Sure. It's data manipulation language, aka an Insert/Update/Drop/Create, or everything except a query. I think BigQuery is the only place I've seen this term.
Flagging this: needs review by someone more Spring savvy

I expect to revisit it when I do the perf testing ticket. I think it's going to be important to schedule a couple of these soon after the initial delivery if we can.
Is there a  way to flag it as read-only if I don't use the template stuff?
@Transactional(readOnly = true)
nit: could you flip this to size > 0?  I find that more readable

this name is misleading - there is one row per workspace.  This is not Workspace 1's rows.
Please also assert that there are 3 workspaces here.
should we test the streaming version of this?
We do, right below. There's no manual batching with the stream approach though. The BQ client does that for us I'm assuming.
What is the advantage of programmatic vs declarative transaction management in the case?

It's nice to have an explicit transaction boundary. I haven't yet gotten to  the point where I trust @Transactional, but I may get there. I also didn't think I could set it to read only using the annotation initially, though that certainly appears doable.
I  suppose I  could also do manual rollback or reporting of status, but I'm not sure how much sense that makes. Basically it's just reassuring to see something as important as a transaction have actual code describing it.
So no real justification I guess. I can convert back to @Transactional if that's the standard.

I prefer to stay away from programmatic transaction management in most cases as it ties the code to transaction management logic. This seems like a pretty straight forward situation that is perfect for @Transactional.
Do we use this enum for anything? Recovering from bad states or is that coming in a future PR?

nodes.bodyText: Not yet. It's either coming out, or will be incorporated into a more sophisticated return type. I haven't decided whether to roll up exceptions and keep going or not. But I have an error handling/correcting story in the backlog.

nodes.bodyText: @jmthibault79 here is the streaming test. It's actually a bit harder to unit test, because not all of the conversions are documented (which gave me fits).

Note  I'm testing two different implementations of upload here. All this fanciness is really only necessary because my local DB doesn't have nearly as many rows as the Test DB, but I don't want to get into a one-off deployments. We can also compare test against Perf, for example.
dupe

Per Spring documentation:
Method visibility and @Transactional
When using proxies, you should apply the @Transactional annotation only to methods with public visibility. If you do annotate protected, private or package-visible methods with the @Transactional annotation, no error is raised, but the annotated method does not exhibit the configured transactional settings.
The annotation needs to exist on method called from outside the proxy class. So the takeSnapshot method would be a candidate for the annotation.
Oh ok. I was hoping to avoid the time to convert the entries extending the transaction any longer, but I bet that's negligible in practice.
